posts.text: Lit review of shame. Shoutout to the one paper from the AI Safety community I found (MIT Media Lab) that was published in March, and does in fact include a handful OpenAI researchers, albeit at the very end of the author list.

reply_context.text:
Poking around the literature, it seems most of the relevant literature exploring this has been coming out of -- wait for it -- BUSINESS SCHOOLS.

To aspiring AI safety researchers: this is an embarrassingly greenfield area with potential for high impact. Please: collaborate with the psych dept.

posts.text:
Poking around the literature, it seems most of the relevant literature exploring this has been coming out of -- wait for it -- BUSINESS SCHOOLS.

To aspiring AI safety researchers: this is an embarrassingly greenfield area with potential for high impact. Please: collaborate with the psych dept.

OpenAI has been harping about "safety" concerns since GPT2. Yet, the potential mental health impacts from chatbot interaction have never been part of the "AI Safety" community's research agenda.

Maybe this young man's death was avoidable, maybe not. Either way, ChatGPT's role in it definitely was.

reply_context.text: fun fact: in the AI biz, what you call "glazing" and think makes your data useless we call an "augmentation". it actually makes your data better. if the data is all the same the model tends to memorize it. if you vary it up in complicated ways the model has to learn how to make sense of it instead.
